mn139:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn139:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
mn139:2.1: “Mendicants, I shall teach you the analysis of non-conflict.
mn139:2.2: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
mn139:3.1: “Don’t indulge in sensual pleasures, which are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.
mn139:3.2: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One woke up by understanding the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.
mn139:3.3: Know what it means to flatter and to rebuke.
mn139:3.4: Knowing these, avoid them, and just teach Dhamma.
mn139:3.5: Know how to assess different kinds of pleasure.
mn139:3.7: Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.
mn139:3.9: Don’t insist on local terminology and don’t override normal usage.
mn139:3.10: This is the recitation passage for the analysis of non-conflict.

mn139:7.1: And how is there flattering and rebuking without teaching Dhamma?
mn139:7.2: In speaking like this, some are rebuked: ‘Pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. All those who indulge in such happiness are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’
mn139:7.4: In speaking like this, some are flattered: ‘Pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. All those who have broken off such indulgence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’
mn139:7.6: In speaking like this, some are rebuked: ‘Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. All those who indulge in it are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’
mn139:7.8: In speaking like this, some are flattered: ‘Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. All those who have broken off such indulgence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’
mn139:7.10: In speaking like this, some are rebuked: ‘All those who have not given up the fetters of rebirth are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’

mn139:9.1: ‘Know how to assess different kinds of pleasure.
mn139:9.3: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
mn139:9.4: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
mn139:9.6: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
mn139:9.10: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
mn139:9.11: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
mn139:9.12: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure—a filthy, common, ignoble pleasure.
mn139:9.13: Such pleasure should not be cultivated or developed, but should be feared, I say.
mn139:9.14: Now, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn139:9.15: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption …
mn139:9.18: This is called the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening.
mn139:9.19: Such pleasure should be cultivated and developed, and should not be feared, I say.
mn139:9.20: ‘Know how to assess different kinds of pleasure.
mn139:9.22: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
mn139:10.1: ‘Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.’
mn139:10.3: but why did I say it?
mn139:10.4: When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is untrue, false, and harmful, then if at all possible you should not speak.
mn139:10.5: When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is true and correct, but harmful, then you should train yourself not to speak.
mn139:10.6: When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is true, correct, and beneficial, then you should know the right time to speak.
mn139:10.7: When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are untrue, false, and harmful, then if at all possible you should not speak.
mn139:10.8: When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are true and correct, but harmful, then you should train yourself not to speak.
mn139:10.9: When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are true, correct, and beneficial, then you should know the right time to speak.
mn139:10.10: ‘Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.’

mn139:11.3: When speaking hurriedly, your body gets tired, your mind gets stressed, your voice gets stressed, your throat gets sore, and your words become unclear and hard to understand.
mn139:11.4: When not speaking hurriedly, your body doesn’t get tired, your mind doesn’t get stressed, your voice doesn’t get stressed, your throat doesn’t get sore, and your words are clear and easy to understand.

mn139:12.1: ‘Don’t insist on local terminology and don’t override normal usage.’
mn139:12.2: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
mn139:12.3: And how do you insist on local terminology and override normal usage?
mn139:12.4: It’s when in different localities the same thing is known as a ‘plate’, a ‘bowl’, a ‘cup’, a ‘dish’, a ‘basin’, a ‘tureen’, or a ‘porringer’.
mn139:12.5: And however it is known in those various localities, you speak accordingly, obstinately sticking to that and insisting:
mn139:12.6: ‘This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’
mn139:12.7: That’s how you insist on local terminology and override normal usage.
mn139:12.8: And how do you not insist on local terminology and not override normal usage?
mn139:12.9: It’s when in different localities the same thing is known as a ‘plate’, a ‘bowl’, a ‘cup’, a ‘dish’, a ‘basin’, a ‘tureen’, or a ‘porringer’.
mn139:12.10: And however it is known in those various localities, you speak accordingly, thinking: ‘It seems that the venerables are referring to this.’
mn139:12.11: That’s how you don’t insist on local terminology and don’t override normal usage.
